history.content:
As it has always been, you must be able to enroll in all components of a class to get into the class.

(You say "waitlisted for both discussion and lecture", but this is redundant: there is only "waitlisted for all components of the class" or "waitlisted for none".)

It has never been the case that "your discussion waitlist position was the only position that mattered".

What is true is that discussions are usually the bottleneck in enrollment, and not lecture (if there's space in lecture, there's usually space in at least one discussion).

It used be that if you were waitlisted for both discussion and lecture, your discussion waitlist position was the only position that mattered, and you could switch to discussions with shorter waitlists to have a better chance of getting into the class. Is this still the case?
history.subject: Does switching discussions still help getting off the waitlist?
